description: JONESBORO- The Jonesboro Land Bank Commission no longer has a dedicated employee, but Mayor Harold Perrin said the relatively new city agency will continue to do its work, with the help of other city departments. Jonathan Smith, who had served as land bank director for two years, resigned in April to move with his family to Murfreesboro, Tenn.. Michael Tyner, director...
text:
JONESBORO - The Jonesboro Land Bank Commission no longer has a dedicated
employee, but Mayor Harold Perrin said the relatively new city agency will
continue to do its work, with the help of other city departments.

Jonathan Smith, who had served as land bank director for two years, resigned
in April to move with his family to Murfreesboro, Tenn.

Because of the economic downturn created by the coronavirus pandemic and other
factors, Perrin said he doesn't plan to search for a replacement.

"We felt like that, at least for now, we would not have need for a director,"
Perrin told the city council's finance and administration committee Tuesday.
The committee endorsed a proposal to use part of the land bank salary to
create a new code enforcement officer's position.

Total annual salary and benefits for the land bank director's position was
$73,450. The cost of the new code enforcement officer for the remainder of the
year would be $24,450.

Perrin said there's a growing need for code enforcement. Michael Tyner,
director of code enforcement, said his four existing code enforcement officers
are spread thin over 80 square miles.

"We're running anywhere from 400 to 500 cases a month, and that's not even
keeping up," Tyner said.

The land bank commission was established in 2018 to fight blight, increase
home ownership, stabilize property values in neighborhoods and provide
affordable housing. Other goals include improving the health and safety of
neighborhoods and maintaining the architectural fabric of the community.

The commission has already acquired property on Drake and North Bridge streets
through donations or redemption of delinquent property, and bought a house on
Warner Avenue that had become dilapidated.

At least for the remainder of the year, Planning Director Derrel Smith and his
staff will pick up most of Jonathan Smith's former responsibilities. The city
collector's office, which is part of the finance department, will pick up
responsibility for preparing liens to be filed against property owners who owe
the city for code enforcement actions, such as demolition of dilapidated
buildings or mowing grass on vacant lots, Perrin said.

title: Mayor proposes shift in some jobs
html:
JONESBORO - The Jonesboro Land Bank Commission no longer has a dedicated employee, but Mayor Harold Perrin said the relatively new city agency will continue to do its work, with the help of other city departments.

Jonathan Smith, who had served as land bank director for two years, resigned in April to move with his family to Murfreesboro, Tenn.

Because of the economic downturn created by the coronavirus pandemic and other factors, Perrin said he doesn't plan to search for a replacement.

"We felt like that, at least for now, we would not have need for a director," Perrin told the city council's finance and administration committee Tuesday. The committee endorsed a proposal to use part of the land bank salary to create a new code enforcement officer's position.

Total annual salary and benefits for the land bank director's position was $73,450. The cost of the new code enforcement officer for the remainder of the year would be $24,450.

Perrin said there's a growing need for code enforcement. Michael Tyner, director of code enforcement, said his four existing code enforcement officers are spread thin over 80 square miles.

"We're running anywhere from 400 to 500 cases a month, and that's not even keeping up," Tyner said.

The land bank commission was established in 2018 to fight blight, increase home ownership, stabilize property values in neighborhoods and provide affordable housing. Other goals include improving the health and safety of neighborhoods and maintaining the architectural fabric of the community.

The commission has already acquired property on Drake and North Bridge streets through donations or redemption of delinquent property, and bought a house on Warner Avenue that had become dilapidated.

At least for the remainder of the year, Planning Director Derrel Smith and his staff will pick up most of Jonathan Smith's former responsibilities. The city collector's office, which is part of the finance department, will pick up responsibility for preparing liens to be filed against property owners who owe the city for code enforcement actions, such as demolition of dilapidated buildings or mowing grass on vacant lots, Perrin said.
